text: A Problem Set on Number Theory and Combinatorics Aditya Ghosh 1. For integers a, b, show that (i) 3 | a2 + b2 implies 3 | a and 3 | b, (ii) 7 | a2 + b2 implies 7 | a and 7 | b. 2. For integers a, b, c, show that 6 | a + b + c if and only if 6 | a3 + b3 + c3. 3. For any n ∈ N, let S(n) denote the sum of the digits of n (in base 10). Show that for every n ∈ N, 9 | n − S(n). 4. Suppose that a natural number m is obtained by rearranging the digits of another natural number n. Show that m − n must be divisible by 9. 5. Show that a − b | an − bn for every n ∈ N and a + b | an + bn for any odd n ∈ N. 6. Show that, (i) if n is not a prime, then 2n − 1 is not a prime, and (ii) if n has an odd divisor, then 2n + 1 is not prime. 7. Find all prime numbers p such that p2 + 11 has exactly 6 different (positive) divisors, includ- ing 1 and itself. 8. Find all prime numbers p, q, such that p2 − 2q2 = 1. 9. If p and p2 + 2 are primes, then show that p3 + 2 is also a prime. 10. Does there exist integers x and y satisfying 15x2 − 7y2 = 9? 11. Find all positive integers N such that N (N − 101) is a perfect square. 12. Prove that n(2310 − n) is not divisible by 2310 for any natural number n < 2310. 13. For any d ∈ N, show that the set {2, 5, 13, d} contains two integers a and b such that ab − 1 is not a perfect square. 14. Prove that any natural number n ≥ 12 can be written as the sum of two composite numbers. 15. Prove that if k is odd then n(n + 1) divides 2(1k + 2k + · · · + nk) for every n ∈ N. 16. Show that the product of any four consecutive positive integers is not a perfect square. 17. Show that the sum of squares of ﬁve consecutive positive integers is never a perfect square. 18. Find all 4-digit perfect squares whose ﬁrst two digits are equal and the last two digits are also equal. 19. When (a + b)(e + f )(i + j)(o + p)(u + v) is expanded, how many terms will be there? Among them how many terms have at least two vowels? 20. There are 8 CCTV cameras in a shop. Find the number of ON-OFF patterns of the cameras if at least three cameras have to be ON all the times. 21. Find the number of ways in which 8 persons, numbered 1 to 8, can be seated in a round table such that 1 always sits between 2 and 3. 1 22. Consider all permutations of 1,2,3,4,5. If we list them in increasing order, what will be the 100-th number in that list? Also, ﬁnd the rank of the number 35421 in that list. 23. Find the number of positive integers less than or equal to 1000 that are divisible by 6, 10, or 15. 24. Find the number of 6-digit natural numbers which have no digit repeated, even digits oc- curring at even places, odd digits occurring at odd places and are divisible by 4. 25. Find the number of 6-digit natural numbers whose digits are chosen from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} and each digit (that appears) appears at least twice. 26. Find the number of ways to select a set of three numbers from the set {1, 2, · · · , 2019} such that they form an Arithmetic Progression. 27. Alice needs to move from (0, 0) to (5, 5), moving either one unit up or one unit to the right at each step. However, she cannot walk from (2, 2) to (2, 3) because a wall is in the way. Find the number of different paths for Alice. 28. A cube has each of its faces coloured with a distinct colour. How many distinct sets of colours can you get by capturing a photo of the cube on a camera? Note, the ordering of the colours is not considered here. (Be careful: any set of two/three colours might not be seen together because of their positions in the cube.) 29. Suppose you go to a stationary shop to buy notebooks. If the shop sells notebooks of 5 different designs for the cover page and you want to buy 8 notebooks such that no design for the cover pages is missed, ﬁnd the number of ways to pick such a desired set of notebooks. Note, here ordering does not matter. 30. Suppose you went to a restaurant with ﬁve friends of yours. After having dinner, you decide to have ice-creams, one ice-cream per person. The menu card shows that the restaurant serves 8 ﬂavours of ice-creams. (a) In how many ways can you select the six ﬂavours to be ordered, such that each one of you get a different ﬂavour than others? (b) Suppose that the waiter comes and says that only 3 ﬂavours (out of the 8) are available. In how many ways can you select the six ﬂavours to be ordered, such that no ﬂavour is missed? Note: In this problem, ordering of the ﬂavours should be taken into account. (Imagine that the waiter writes them one by one as an ordered list.) 31. Call a positive integer monotonous if it is a one-digit number or its digits, when read from left to right, form either a strictly increasing or a strictly decreasing sequence. For example, 3, 23578, and 987620 are monotonous, but 88, 7434, and 23557 are not. Find the number of monotonous positive integers (of all possible digits). 32. In how many ways can one split 2n distinct objects into n pairs? (The ordering of the pairs is immaterial.) 2 33. In how many ways can you select 4 numbers from {1, 2, . . . , n} such that among the chosen numbers, no two are consecutive? (Assume that n ≥ 7.) 34. For k ≥ 1, simplify the sum: ( n 0 ) + ( n + 1 1 ) + ( n + 2 2 ) + · · · + ( n + k k ). 35. Find the number of integer solutions of the equation x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 = 100 if it is given that xi > i − 1 for each 1 ≤ i ≤ 4. 36. Find the number of 4-tuples (ordered list of 4 numbers) (a, b, c, d) of non-negative integers such that a + b + c + d ≤ 100. 37. Determine the number of ways to select 3 distinct integers from the set {1, 2, . . . , 30} such that their sum is divisible by 3. 38. Let p, q be positive integers such that 1 − 1 2 + 1 3 − 1 4 + · · · + 1 1335 = p q . Show that 2003 | p. 39. The powers 2n and 5n start with the same digit d. What is this digit d? 40. Find all positive integers n such that 5n + 1 is divisible by 7. 41. Let n be any natural number. Suppose that d is the gcd of n2 + 20 and (n + 1)2 + 20. Show that d must be a divisor of 81. 42. How many pairs of positive integers (x, y) are there that satisfy the equation 1 x + 1 y = 1 10 ? Here (x, y) and (y, x) are considered to be different, when x ̸= y. Can you generalise? (Replace 10 by any positive integer of your choice.) 43. Suppose N is a nine-digit number, in which every digit except zero occurs and which ends with 5. Prove that N cannot be a square. 44. Suppose for some positive integers r and s, the number 2r is obtained by rearranging the digits of 2s (in decimal representation). Prove that we must have r = s. 45. A number n has distinct digits and the digits are in increasing order from left to right. Prove that the sum of the digits of the number 9n will always be 9. 46. A natural number n is chosen strictly between two consecutive perfect squares. The smaller of these two squares is k less that n and the larger one is ℓ more than n. Prove that, n − kℓ is a perfect square. 47. Is it possible to write the numbers 17, 18, 19, . . . , 32 in a 4 × 4 grid of unit squares, with one number in each square, such that if the grid is divided into four 2 × 2 sub-grids of unit squares then the product of numbers in each of the sub-grids divisible by 16? 48. Find all primes p and q such that p divides q2 − 4 and q divides p2 − 1. 49. Find all 4-tuples (a, b, c, d) of natural numbers with a ≤ b ≤ c and a! + b! + c! = 3d. 50. Given a positive integer n, let p(n) be the product of the nonzero digits of n. (If n has only one digit, then p(n) is equal to that digit.) Let S = p(1) + p(2) + · · · + p(999). What is the largest prime factor of S? 3 51. In a book with page numbers from 1 to 100, some pages are torn off. The sum of the numbers on the remaining pages is 4949. How many pages are torn off? 52. Find all integers n for which n2 + 19n + 92 is a perfect square. 53. Find all pairs of non-negative integers (x, y) satisfying x3 + 8x2 − 6x + 8 = y3. 54. Prove that a 20-digit number starting with 11 ones cannot be a perfect square. 55. Can you ﬁnd all integers m, n that satisfy m2 + (m + 1)2 = n4 + (n + 1)4? 56. If n is a positive integer such that 2n + 1 and 3n + 1 both are perfect squares then show that (i) n must be divisible by 40, and (ii) 5n + 3 can not be a prime. 57. Let a, b, c ∈ N such that a2 + b2 = c2 and c − b = 1. Prove that, (i) a must be odd, (ii) b must be divisible by 4, and (iii) ab + ba must be divisible by c. 58. For each n ∈ N deﬁne an = (3 + √ 5)n + (3 − √5)n. Show that, (i) an is an integer for every n ≥ 1. (ii) an+1 = 6an − 4an−1 for every n ≥ 2. (iii) an is divisible by 2n for every n ≥ 1. 59. Suppose a1, a2, . . . is a sequence of positive integers satisfying n∑ k=1 a 3 k = ( n∑ k=1 ak)2 for every positive integer n. Is it necessarily true that ak = k for each k? 60. Suppose that f : N → N is a function satisfying f (m + n) ≤ f (m) + f (n) for every m, n ∈ N. Show that for every n ≥ 1, f (1) + f (2) 2 + f (3) 3 + · · · + f (n) n ≥ f (n). 61. Call a positive integer n good if there are n integers, positive or negative, and not necessarily distinct, such that their sum and products are both equal to n. Show that all the integers of the form 4k + 1 and 4l are good. 62. Let {xn} be a sequence of real numbers starting with x1 = 1 2 and satisfying xk+1 = x2 k + xk for all k ≥ 1. Determine the greatest integer less than or equal to 1 x1 + 1 + 1 x2 + 1 + · · · + 1 x2020 + 1 . 63. Solve the following system of equations: x + ⌊y⌋ + {z} = 200.0, {x} + y + ⌊z⌋ = 190.1, ⌊x⌋ + {y} + z = 178.8. Here ⌊x⌋ denotes the greatest integer ≤ x, and {x} denotes x − ⌊x⌋. 64. For positive integers n and r, ﬁnd the gcd of the following numbers: ( n r ) , (n + 1 r ) , ( n + 2 r ) , · · · , ( n + r r ). 4 65. Consider an n × n array of numbers aij (standard notation). Suppose each row consists of the n numbers 1, 2, . . . , n in some order and aij = aji for i, j = 1, 2, . . . , n. If n is odd, prove that the numbers a11, a22, . . . ann must be 1, 2, 3, . . . , n in some order. 66. If 4n + 2n + 1 is a prime number (n ∈ N) then show that n must be a power of 3. 67. Consider a sequence a1, a2, . . . deﬁned as an = 2n + 3n + 6n − 1, n ≥ 1. Determine all positive integers that are coprime to every term of the sequence. 68. Let a1, a2, . . . , an be n numbers such that each ai is either 1 or −1. If a1a2 + a2a3 + · · · + an−1an + ana1 = 0, then show that n must be a multiple of 4. 69. In how many ways can you ﬁll up an m × n array of numbers with ±1 such that product of the numbers in each row and each column becomes −1? (Hint: consider different cases, depending on whether m, n are even or odd.) 70. In how many ways can you colour 6 faces of a dice with 6 different colours, using each colour exactly once? 71. In how many ways can a row of 10 squares be each colored either red or green in such a way that no two red squares are adjacent? 72. Consider all n-words from the alphabet {0, 1, 2, 3}. How many of them have an even number of (a) zeros, (b) zeros and ones? 73. Suppose 32 objects are placed on the circumference of a circle, at equal distances. In how many ways can 3 objects be chosen from among them so that no two of the three chosen objects are adjacent nor diametrically opposite? 74. Consider the smallest number in each of the (n r) subsets (of size r) of S = {1, 2, . . . , n}. Show that the arithmetic mean of the numbers so obtained is n+1 r+1 . 75. A ten digit number is called interesting if its digits are distinct and is divisible by 11111. Find the number of such interesting numbers. 76. Find all natural numbers n such that 1 + ⌊√2n⌋ is a divisor of 2n. 77. For any n ∈ N, show that there is an n-digit number which consists of the digits 1 and 2 only and is divisible by 2n. 78. For every m ∈ N, show that there exist n ∈ N such that m + n + 1 is a perfect square and mn + 1 is a perfect cube. 79. Find all triples of positive integer (x, y, z) for which the this expression is a perfect square: x2 + y2 + z2 + 2xy + 2x(z − 1) + 2y(z + 1). 80. Solve in integers the following system of equations: x2 + 6y2 = u2, 6x2 + y2 = v2. 81. Does there exist integers x, y that satisfy the equation x3 + 7 = y2? 82. Solve in positive integers the equation x2 + 5 = y3. 83. Find all pairs of positive integers (p, n) where p is a prime and p3 − p = n7 − n3. 5 84. Find all x, y, z, t, n ∈ N satisfying the equation nx + ny + nz = nt. 85. Let xn be the n-th non-square integer. For example, x1 = 2, x2 = 3, x3 = 5 and so on. Now, let us denote by ⟨n⟩ the integer nearest to √n. Prove that (i) xn = n + ⟨n⟩, and (ii) if m2 n < xn < (mn + 1)2 then mn = ⟨n⟩. 86. Prove that there is no integer n > 1 for which n | 2n − 1. 87. Find all positive integers n with divisors 1 = d1 < d2 < d3 < . . . such that d13 + d14 + d15 = n and (d5 + 1)3 = d15 + 1. 88. The arithmetic derivative D(n) of a positive integer n is deﬁned via the following rules: (a) D(p) = 1 for all primes p, and D(1) = 0, (b) D(ab) = bD(a) + aD(b) for all positive integers a and b. Find the sum of all positive integers n below 2019 satisfying D(n) = n. 89. Suppose α is an irrational number, 0 < α < 1. Prove that, there exist inﬁnitely many n ∈ N such that ⌊nα⌋ is even and ⌊2nα⌋ is odd. 90. Let p be a prime number greater than 5. Suppose the decimal representation of 1/p looks like 0.a1a2 . . . ar where the line denotes a recurring decimal. Prove that, 10r leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by p. 91. Suppose {an} is a sequence such that a0 = a1 = 5 and an = (an−1 + an+1)/98 for all n ∈ N. Prove that, (an + 1)/6 is a perfect square for every non-negative integer n. 92. Find all n ∈ N such that (2n n ) is divisible by 4. 93. Let B(m) denote the set of integers r for which 2r is a term in the binary expansion of m. For example, B(100) = {2, 5, 6}. Prove that, (n k) is odd if and only if B(k) ⊆ B(n). 94. Show that we can choose 2k distinct numbers from {0, 1, 2, . . . , 3k − 1}, such that three num- bers in arithmetic progression will not occur among the chosen numbers. 95. Let n > 1 be a positive integer. For how many numbers a in S = {2, 3, . . . , n2 − 1} is a2 − a divisible by n2? 96. Alice is going from (0, 0) to (n, n). In each step, she either moves one unit to the right or one unit upwards. Find number of paths for Alice, which never cross the line y = x. 97. Using a combinatorial argument, prove the identity n∑ k=0 ( n k )(n + k k ) = n∑ k=0 2k( n k )2. 98. Let S be a set of n ≥ 1 elements, and let A1, A2, . . . , Ak be a family of distinct subsets of S, with the property that any two of these subsets have non-empty intersection. And suppose that for any other subset B of S, there is an Ai such that B ∩Ai is empty. Prove that k = 2n−1. (Hint: First show that k ≤ 2n−1.) 99. Prove the identity n∑ k=0 (n + k k ) 1 2k = 2 n. (Hint: Toss a fair coin.) 100. Let a0 = a1 = 1 and an+1 = 7an − an−1 − 2 for all n ∈ N. Prove that, an is a perfect square for all n ≥ 0. 6
